text: Donald Lawrence Keene (June 18, 1922 - February 24, 2019), also known as , "Donald Keene obtains Japanese citizenship; shows off 鬼怒鳴門 as his name," Japan Today. March 9, 2001; retrieved 2012-11-18. was an American and Japanese scholar, teacher, writer, translator and Japan studies expert.Fackler, Martin. "Lifelong Scholar of the Japanese Becomes One of Them," The New York Times, November 2, 2012; retrieved 2012-11-02. Keene's contributions to the understanding of Japanese culture were recognized by the Japanese government in 2002 and in 2008.Keene Center of Japanese Culture, About Donald Keene ; retrieved 2012-11-02. In 2012, Keene became a Japanese citizen and he explained, :"You cannot stop being an American after 89 years.... But I have become a Japanese in many ways. Not pretentiously, but naturally." ==Early life== Keene was born in Brooklyn in New York City.Pilling, David. "Lunch with the FT: Donald Keene," 28 October 2011; retrieved 2012-11-5. He received a Bachelor's degree from Columbia in 1942. He studied Japanese language at the U.S. Navy Japanese Language School. After World War II, he returned to Columbia where he earned a master's degree in 1947. He earned a Ph.D. from Columbia in 1951. In this period, Ryūsaku Tsunoda became his mentor.Arita, Eriko. "Keene: A life lived true to the words," Japan Times. September 6, 2009; retrieved 2012-11-18. ==Career== Starting in 1955,Library of Congress Authority File, Keene, Donald; retrieved 2012-11-02. Keene was a professor at Columbia University for over fifty years. He retired from Columbia after the 2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami. He became a Japanese citizen under the name Kīn Donarudo. His first visit to Japan was during the Battle of Okinawa in 1945. ==Death== Keene died on February 24, 2019 in Tokyo from heart failure, aged 96.ドナルド・キーンさん死去 96歳 ==Selected works== In an overview of writings by and about Keene, OCLC/WorldCat lists roughly 600+ works in 1,400+ publications in 16 languages and 39,000+ library holdings.
